review_text:
My husband and I, and our two pups, stayed at Grit & Grace Lodge for three nights for our anniversary, and we loved it! The space was beautiful and relaxing, and the high ceilings and rustic, simple décor made it feel open and welcoming. Even though it's in close proximity to the host's home, it felt very private.
The kitchen was current and well appointed, to include fresh roasted coffee beans and a grinder! We had everything we needed to make some great meals, and it was especially nice to have Prenger grocery store only 4 miles away to pick up anything we needed.
The bathroom was clean and spacious, had ample amenities, and the huge shower with the waterfall showerhead was wonderful after a long day of being out-and-about! We also appreciated having the washer and dryer available.
There were two bedrooms, each thoughtfully decorated and cozy. With it just being the two of us, we used one to sleep in each night, and the other as a makeshift closet and to keep our bags organized. If you're traveling with a larger group who may need to use the second bedroom for sleeping, you may want to be aware that it is essentially a finished garage - with a functioning lift door and everything - with a bed, rug, and chair. It didn't bother us in the least so it did not impact our rating at all, but it was pretty chilly in that room at night. Also, be aware that the floors throughout the lodge are sealed concrete, which was wonderful for the pups, but they are chilly as well. Bring slippers, and you won't even notice!
We thoroughly enjoyed walks with our dogs around the pond path in the early mornings and at sunset, and we enjoyed feeding the fish on the lovely dock, and taking them for walks around the farm to see the friendly goats and highland calf. It was an added treat when the hosts met us outside one day to talk about the farm, and let us into the pen to feed the goats and interact with the animals! We loved it! They also had a very nice corn hole set outside.
If you don't mind meandering drives down pretty country roads (we recommend doing so with the windows down and blaring your favorite tunes!), the lodge is also in nice proximity to Mark Twain Lake and the Union Covered Bridge, which was breathtaking to see with the surrounding Fall foliage. We even drove into Hannibal to visit the Folklife Festival and have dinner one day, and didn't at all mind the miles in between!
One night when we arrived back at the lodge, we found that the hosts had built us a fire in the fire pit and set out two chairs for us to enjoy it. The sky was clear and full of stars....it was so thoughtful, and we appreciated it so much!
The only other thing I can think to mention would be to prepare to entertain yourself, and you'll thoroughly enjoy this stay! There is only one TV in one of the bedrooms, and it is a smart TV with streaming only. That said, while we were there, the internet and WiFi were out for the duration of our stay, so there was essentially no TV. In that area, it's also hard to come by a cell signal, so if you are hoping to check emails, send/receive important texts, access social media, etc., you may not be able to until you're off-site a ways. Again, this did not bother us at all (we actually enjoyed the “detox”…lol) so it didn’t impact our rating, and the hosts were very apologetic and tried everything they could to get it fixed while we were there. They were extremely responsive, accommodating, and kind, and we wouldn’t hesitate to book another stay at Grit & Grace!
If you’re looking for a relaxing, pet-friendly stay in a country setting with everything you need to unplug and get away from crowds and traffic, this is it!

Feeding the fish in the evenings was relaxing and peaceful. Hearing the rooster in the morning while enjoying a cup of coffee, and watching the goats play only added to the serene atmosphere. Did I mention the coffee? The host also owns a coffee shop and has a special blend at Grit and Grace waiting for you. But the most important thing was that, since this was a sister's weekend retreat, we felt safe the moment we pulled in. We slept well the first night there. If you love to travel for getaways, but that first night is always an adjustment, Grit and Grace is a place you should consider. Seriously, one of the best places I've ever stayed!

The only downsides: The larger of the 3 mattresses left my husband and I’s feet hanging off the bottom even though we are only 5ft 7”-5ft 9”. There was some expired food in the fridge and kitchen cabinet. But it was a very clean kitchen even with that.
If you mind a train whistle at night this place is not for you. If you are used to it or even enjoy it, it’s perfect!

O’s Barn Cabin was a perfect last minute get away for an anniversary trip. With three kids and jobs it’s often difficult to find time to connect. The Barn offered exactly that much needed time.
Aaron was gracious and let us check in an hour early so we can get settled. The cabin is rustically decorated and comfortable. Though we didn’t use it, other than to check the football and baseball scores, the projector tv is fun!
We were really interested in an evening around the fire pit. While we went to an early dinner, Aaron retrieved some excellent fire wood for us to burn.
We highly recommend Lula’s Tavern for dinner. They offer a limited menu of steak, seafood and burgers, but well worth it. They open at 4 pm. Get there when they open or you will be waiting. It’s a place with great character and you walk in and you instantly feel like family. Everyone knows each other! Heads up, like any family, they only take cash or checks.
We returned from our dinner and had a wonderful evening by the fire and watching shooting stars into the night.
Thank you Aaron!

The porch offered a lovely view in the mornings (although sadly no cows spotted), and I found the couch to be really comfortable to sleep on. There are also air mattresses readily available. The downsides we experienced were that it was a little dusty and some kitchen surfaces didn't seem like they had been cleaned. The bathroom doesn't offer much privacy, which is understandable for a small cabin, but still something to keep in mind if you're anxious about that sort of thing like I am LOL. Also, while the covered windows provided the best experience for video games and movies on the projector, it also meant the cabin was a bit darker throughout the day. There wasn't an easy option for letting more light in, and I really wish there had been since the days were sunny and it would have been nice to enjoy the view without always needing to step outside.

review_text:
This cabin on a private lake is perfect in every way. This level of natural beauty and privacy is rare to find at most AirBnbs in rural Missouri (I’ve stayed at quite a few).
Its quiet seclusion means you only hear bird calls with your morning coffee and a symphony of frogs accompanies evening star gazing. I was shocked by how FEW bug bites I got compared with how much time I spent outside - yes, there were bugs, but unlike my place in the city, the bugs didn’t swarm and ruin the outside. The exterior spaces are well thought out and furnished for relaxation, even the few trees sloping down to the lake are perfectly spaced to hang your hammocks for lazy afternoon naps. We loved the porch swing facing the bird feeder and marveled at the frequent hummingbird visitors.
This is an old, rustic cabin but the total interior renovation ensures just about every amenity you need while preserving the rough-hewn log look. There was plenty of space for the two of us to spread out on the tasteful furniture and enjoy postcard views from the large picture windows. The photos don’t do justice to just how lovely this space feels in person. We used the pool table and dart board quite a bit, those were an unexpected bonus.
The beds were super comfortable and good window shades kept the morning light away! The kitchen is well equipped - some of the sharpest knives of any rental - and had what we needed to prepare most of our meals from scratch.
We lucked out and found a slice of heaven in mid-Missouri. I NEVER book un-reviewed AirBnbs, but a last minute scramble to reserve some peace and quiet for the weekend overcame my usual caution. I’ve stayed in A LOT of rentals and this is one of the very best. We plan to return when the leaves begin to change colors.
The owners were excellent in all communication and the caretakers we had occasion to meet, Rob and Sue, were absolutely delightful and gave us lots of tips about the surrounding nature.

This was my favorite bnb ever and I've stayed in quite a few spots. Host was communicative, directions were clear, the spot is so private, the lights were on when I arrived, and there was a pleasant essential oil diffuser going that made everything smell lovely. You look out onto the most verdant field of fireflies at dusk with deer and rabbits running around. The dog is SUPER friendly and adorable. I loved every second.
The people who wrote long paragraphs trashing this families spot are lunatics or didn't read the description. It's a literal BARN, people. It's a super deal, there are campsites with zero amenities on Airbnb that cost more than this. There is hardly any cell service, the fridge is ancient ( but so cold) , a little dust and there are bugs outside unless you leave the door open then they will come inside. I had to drive through a wall of butterflies and dragonflies when I left so don't know what the person who wanted to experience more nature was talking about. The water pump makes a healthy sounds that reminds you to conserve it. NoTV only a stereo with radio and records. These are all things that enhanced the off grid experience. And there were no mice or signs of them.
I so appreciate spots like this and hope this family continues to host on this site regardless of the occasional confused person.

review_text: This place is definitely off the grid a little bit (in a good way!) I had no issues finding the place with the help of GPS and the hotel signs they put up. It is on a gravel road off of a highway, but once you're there you can only hear cars that drive right by you on the gravel road. The parking space is very small which was fine for my small car, but I would be cautious if I had a the combination of a larger vehicle and terrible reverse skills. The hotel itself was very clean! It did have a unique smell on the main room, but I got used to it after five minutes or so. The bed was the comfiest thing I have ever slept on!!! As a 21-one-year old woman traveling by herself rather far away, I studied the reciews of this place like crazy to make sure I would be safe (which I was!) I did notice that one of the reviews stated that there wasn't a top sheet on the bed. That has apparently changed as there was one when I stayed there. The air conditioning worked well and the place was a comfortable temperature. I had a fire both nights I was there and even cooked my own food over the fire on the first night. I saved the leftovers in the fridge and used their kitchen tools to reheat it the second night. My absolute favorite thing about this place was the record player!!! They had a hand full of records, but I mainly played the classical and jazz records. It was bice to listen to amazing records that had more popular pieces in these genres instead of the typical random pieces that you find in most record stores. I had zero service inside the barn and the close surrounding area, but as soon as I got a little farther up the gravel road in my car my phone was dinging insanely with notifications. So if you're really desperate for service you can find some with a two minute walk up the road. Since there was no service I would recommend planning what you are going to do for the day before you get there if you plan on leaving for a while. One of my surprise mini-trips was over to the Walt Disney Hometown Museum and Family Farm. I'm a huge disney fan and had no clue this existed until I searched "attractions" in google maps. It was about an hour drive from the place... This was my first time staying in an Airbnb and traveling by myself hours away from home. To start, communication with Mary was top notch. She responds very quickly and is very thoughtful and friendly.
The surrounding area is so pretty and quiet. Very safe area. My suggestion would be to not arrive after dark. My husband and I drove 13 hours in one day and with inevitable delays along the way, we arrived here after dark. (Also, like the knuckle heads we are, we were listening to spooky mystery cases all evening.) Consequently, we were already a little freaked out when we showed up, in the dark, down a bumpy road, and to top it off we were very tired. It’s also rather difficult to find in the dark. We ended up finding the place after he accidentally passed it, and like any good, stubborn husband, he wouldn’t put the Jeep in reverse to go back, so we had to turn around in a tiny driveway right down the road.
I had completely forgotten to explain the place to him. Needless to say, it wasn’t what he was expecting. When he saw the toilet, he just looked at me... but considering he has willingly spent countless nights in the woods with no porcelain throne to rest his derrière, he had no room to complain. The toilet was different but was no issue. As expected, it did make the place smell a bit like wood shavings, which I actually like. Needless to say, explain where you’re going to your partner BEFORE you get there. Don’t do like I did and just shock them. As a result, he was a little uneasy.
After settling into bed, we heard a noise (which ended up just being the cat outside) and my husband got even more spooked and went to check it out.
But y’all, even after all this, the bed was soooo soft that we slept like babies. I don’t remember waking up once!! It was a really great and much needed sleep.
When we woke up in the morning, we saw that we were in pretty woods and there was a nice field nearby. It’s in a very nice little spot. There’s even a fire pit and chairs. I didn’t look in the fridge or the shower, but the rest of the place was very clean.
Suggestions: try to arrive during the day, make sure you’re driving a vehicle that can handle a bumpy road, keep an open mind and realize this isn’t a $100 hotel room. It’s in the country so there are bugs that wander in, a weird shavings toilet that works just fine, and a bed is on the floor but incredibly soft and comfy. Also, expect a long but beautiful drive off the highway to get here.
If you like quiet and are just fine with these other things, this is the place for you!

This location is on a working farm. While the host's home sits up near the road, the BnB is a good distance back from the road. The farm has a trio of cats that can be a lot fun to watch. They also have a small flock of very colorful, free-range chickens lead around during the day by a particularly handsome rooster. Last, but hardly least, the farm has about 50 head of cattle on it. On a clear night, it is easy to get "out of reach of the barnyard lights" and see oodles of stars!
The BnB itself, was clean and new. As the images indicate, it's a large rectangular space, with a bathroom "carved out" of the northeast corner. It's perfect for a couple wanting to get away for a weekend, or more. (We were there for 3 weeks, "hiding" from the dust and fuss of a significant remodel effort taking place in our home!)
Check out Finger Lakes State Park, just a few miles south of the BnB, as you head to Columbia. There are quaint local eateries, plus lot's of choices in Columbia.

I've never had a better Airbnb experience, and we will happily stay at Woodland Fox Retreat when we return to the area.
